aboutHero.p1: The leading inland property agent ever since 2001.
aboutHero.p2: With offices in inland Málaga (Mollina) and Jaén (Alcalá la Real) we can assist you at every step.
aboutHero.p3: Inland Andalucia is dedicated to finding you the best value inland property in the Andalucia region.
aboutHero.p4: You can select from our constantly updated property portfolio or contact us with your requirements.
aboutHero.p5: In the last three months 80% of our sales were for homes costing less than 100,000 Euros (circa £72.000).
aboutHero.p6: 50% have been costing less than 150,000€ (circa £108.000) and 5% have been more expensive properties, but with great discounts.

values.p1: Our personal attention to your needs will not falter after you have found the inland property of your dreams. We are also happy and willing to help and offer advice on every aspect of your purchase.
values.p2: We should be pleased to help with electricity and water account changes, opening of bank accounts, NIE application etc.
values.p3: You can rely on our long standing experience and superior local knowledge to be the right guide to help you buy your new property in inland Andalucia.
values.p4: We pride ourselves in personalised and good service, trying to give you as much help as possible. As we always want you to have the individual attention you need, please try to reserve an appointment with us before you leave your home, that way we can be ready and available for you personally at a pre-arranged time and date that suits you.

We specialise in the areas of Antequera, Cordoba, Granada, Jaen, Malaga and Sevilla where, with us you will find your ideal inland property. If you do not find what you are looking for please contact us, as we probably have it.

For Each town we have properties for sale, click on the town name to get all the information you need. Luvinland will return you to us to view the properties for sale in the town selected.

section1.heading: About Cordoba
section1.text: The "Jewish Quarter" or old town, with its small plazas, patios full of colourful flowers and typical bars where tapas are enjoyed, is full of amazing architecture. The Mezquita (or mosque) attracts thousands of visitors each year who flock to admire the magnificent workmanship - it took two centuries to complete and is an amazing jungle of columns, recesses and arches with a church at its centre. Outside the mosque are the beautiful gardens, "the Patio de los Naranjos" and the "Calleja de la Flores".

section2.heading: Culture & Heritage
section2.text: Across the river from the Mezquita is the Alcázar (or fortress) which was built by the Christians in 1328 as a defence against the Muslims. It offers a lovely respite from the summer heat as you wander through the tree shaded gardens and courtyards.

section3.heading: Geography & Agriculture
section3.text: As the city is divided, so is the province: The Sierra Morena in the north with its rugged pine and oak covered hills with a few steep villages set into them. The Campiña in the south which are the farmlands covered in wheat, vine and olive trees. The area is famous for its dry white wines, similar to sherry, which are produced from the Pedro Ximenez grape and olive oil, which is the other main produce from the region.

section4.heading: Local Cuisine
section4.text: This is why olive oil is an important ingredient of many typical dishes, Gazpacho and Salmorejo are cold soups made mainly of mashed vegetables and olive oil and are delicious and refreshing in the heat of the summer. Jamon, which is cured ham, Salchichon, a typical sausage, Caña de Lomo and Morcilla, black pudding are also widely enjoyed in the province. Some typical desserts are Alfajores, made of almonds and honey and Pestiños, which is fried in oil and then covered with honey.

section5.heading: Festivals & Events
section5.text: Cordoba enjoys its fiestas and festivals the same as every other town in Spain, and Semana Santa, or Easter week is one of the most important. There are no fewer than 32 processions in total with beautifully decorated and ornate pictures and figures of Saints accompanied by the Nazarenos (men dressed in typical gowns with hoods that cover all the face except the eyes). These processions pass through the town followed by crowds of people. In May there are three festivals; from 5th to 12th there is the Festival of the "Patios Cordobeses", a contest for the most beautifully decorated courtyard; the Cruces de Mayo is when the whole town is decorated with crosses and thousands of flowers; the last week in May is when everyone lets their hair down at the Feria de Cordoba - flamenco music and dance are enjoyed and the whole town revels in the festivities.

section1.heading: About Granada
section1.text: GRANADA Province is situated in the eastern part of the autonomous region of Andalucia, is bordered by the provinces of Málaga, Córdoba, Jaén, Albacete, Murcia, Almería and stretches down to the Mediterranean sea. It's total area is 12,635km2 and contains 168 municipalities.

section2.heading: Natural Beauty
section2.text: Granada province boasts the tallest mountain in continental Spain, Mulhacén, at 3,481 metres as well as the Sierra Nevada mountain range (the most southerly ski resort in Europe). During the winter months, tourists flock to the Sierra Nevada for the skiing and mountain climbing, but Granada city is popular the year round for its Moorish architecture and the famous Alhambra, with its palaces and gardens. Not forgetting the cave dwellings dotted about the Sacromonte hill to the north of the city which was once the home of Granada's large gypsy community.

section3.heading: Cultural Heritage
section3.text: The hill facing the Alhambra is called the Albaicin and if you wind your way up through the narrow streets, past all the whitewashed houses, you will reach the highest point with amazing views of the Alhambra and the many differing landscapes of Granada province.

section4.heading: Outdoor Activities
section4.text: The province offers numerous opportunities for outdoor activities. The Rio Genil is famous for its trout fishing, and the Sierra Nevada provides excellent hiking and climbing opportunities. The Alpujarras region is particularly popular for walking holidays, with its network of ancient paths connecting the white villages.

section1.heading: About Jaen
section1.text: Jaén province is known as the world's capital of olive oil, with endless olive groves covering its rolling hills and valleys. This beautiful inland region is home to Renaissance cities, medieval castles, and natural parks.The province offers an authentic Spanish lifestyle away from the coastal tourist areas, with a rich cultural heritage and stunning natural landscapes such as the Sierra de Cazorla, Segura y Las Villas Natural Park.

section2.heading: Olive Oil Heritage
section2.text: Jaén produces more olive oil than any other region in the world. The vast sea of olive trees covering the landscape is not just economically important but also shapes the culture and gastronomy of the area.

section3.heading: Renaissance Heritage
section3.text: The twin cities of Úbeda and Baeza are UNESCO World Heritage sites, known for their remarkable Renaissance architecture. These historic centers showcase palaces, churches, and plazas built during Spain's Golden Age.

section4.heading: Natural Parks
section4.text: The Sierra de Cazorla, Segura y Las Villas Natural Park is Spain's largest protected area, offering breathtaking mountain scenery, dense forests, rivers, and diverse wildlife including deer and wild boar.

section5.heading: Gastronomy
section5.text: Jaén's cuisine is centered around olive oil, with traditional dishes like pipirrana (vegetable salad), andrajos (stew with flat noodles), and ochíos (aniseed bread) offering authentic flavors of inland Andalucia.

section1.heading: About Malaga
section1.text:
Málaga Province is located in the southern part of Andalucia, along the Mediterranean coast. It's known for its beautiful beaches, stunning mountain ranges, and rich cultural heritage.
The province offers a perfect blend of coastal and inland living, with the Sierra de las Nieves Natural Park and the famous El Torcal de Antequera providing spectacular natural landscapes.

section2.heading: Natural Beauty
section2.text: The province boasts diverse natural landscapes, from the dramatic limestone formations of El Torcal de Antequera to the pristine beaches of the Costa del Sol. The Sierra de las Nieves Natural Park is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.

section3.heading: Cultural Heritage
section3.text: Málaga's cultural heritage spans thousands of years. The city of Málaga features the impressive Alcazaba fortress and Roman Theatre. Antequera is known for its dolmens, prehistoric burial mounds that are UNESCO World Heritage sites..

section4.heading: Local Cuisine
section4.text: Málaga's cuisine reflects its coastal and inland influences. Fresh seafood, particularly fried fish (pescaíto frito), is a local specialty. The province is also known for its sweet wines, particularly Málaga wine.

section5.heading: Festivals & Events
section5.text: The province hosts numerous festivals throughout the year. The Málaga Film Festival attracts international attention, while the Feria de Málaga in August is one of the biggest celebrations in Andalucia.

section1.heading: About Sevilla
section1.text:
Sevilla province is a treasure trove of history, culture, and natural beauty. While famous for its capital city with iconic landmarks like the Giralda and Plaza de España, the inland areas offer a different, more authentic experience.
The province features picturesque white towns, rolling olive groves, and historical sites from various civilizations that have called this region home, from the Romans and Moors to Renaissance and Baroque influences.

section2.heading: Historic Towns
section2.text: Inland Sevilla is home to charming historic towns like Osuna, Écija, Carmona, and Marchena, each with unique architecture and rich heritage. Osuna's Renaissance palaces and Écija's Baroque church towers have earned it the nickname "City of Towers."

section3.heading: Natural Landscapes
section3.text: The province boasts diverse natural landscapes, from the Sierra Norte Natural Park with its dense forests and granite formations, to the fertile Guadalquivir Valley with endless fields of sunflowers, wheat, and olive groves.

section4.heading: Culinary Traditions
section4.text: Sevillian cuisine is a delight for food lovers, featuring specialties like gazpacho, spinach with chickpeas, and Iberian ham. The inland areas are particularly renowned for olive oils, artisanal cheeses, and traditional sweets.

section5.heading: Festivals & Traditions
section5.text: Inland Sevilla comes alive during its traditional festivals. Each town has its own unique celebration, from the elaborate Holy Week processions to vibrant summer ferias, flamenco performances, and agricultural harvesting festivals.

buyers-guide.description: A comprehensive guide to buying property in Spain, from initial viewing to getting your keys. Understanding each step helps ensure a smooth purchase process.

steps.heading: Step 4: Purchase Completion
items: Register the property in your name

steps.heading: After Purchase Support

property-taxes.title: Property Taxes in Spain
property-taxes.description: Understanding the tax implications of buying and owning property in Spain is crucial for making informed decisions. Here's a comprehensive overview of all the taxes involved.

transfer-tax.heading: Transfer Tax (ITP)
transfer-tax.intro: When buying a resale property, you'll need to pay the Property Transfer Tax (ITP):

vat-stamp-duty.heading: VAT (IVA) and Stamp Duty
vat-stamp-duty.intro: For new properties, instead of ITP, you'll pay:

important-note.heading: Important Note
important-note.text: Tax rates can vary between regions in Spain and may change over time. Always consult with a legal professional for the most current rates and regulations.

ibi.heading: IBI (Council Tax)
ibi.intro: The main annual property tax in Spain, based on the cadastral value of your property:
items: Paid annually to the local town hall
Usually between 0.4% and 1.1% of cadastral value

basura.heading: Basura (Rubbish Collection)
basura.intro: Annual fee for waste collection services:
items: Varies by location and property size

non-resident-taxes.heading: Non-Resident Taxes
non-resident-taxes.intro: If you're a non-resident property owner, you'll need to:
items: File an annual income tax return
Pay tax on rental income (if applicable)
Submit Form 210 for imputed income tax

capital-gains-tax.heading: Capital Gains Tax
capital-gains-tax.intro: When selling your property, you'll need to consider:
items: 19-23% tax on the profit made (for non-residents)
Deductions for improvements and buying costs

cta.heading: Need Tax Advice?
cta.text: Our team can connect you with experienced tax advisors who specialize in Spanish property taxation.

faq-content.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq-content.description: Find answers to the most common questions about buying property in inland Spain. If you can't find what you're looking for, don't hesitate to contact us.

questions.q: Do I need to be a resident to buy property in Spain?
questions.a: No, you don’t need to be a resident. Non-residents can freely buy property in Spain, but you’ll need an NIE (Foreign Identity Number) to complete the purchase.

questions.q: What additional costs should I budget for when buying?
questions.a: Budget approximately 10-12% of the purchase price for additional costs, including: transfer tax (6-10%), notary fees, legal fees, and registration fees.

questions.q: How long does the buying process take?
questions.a: The typical buying process takes 2-3 months from offer acceptance to completion. This can vary depending on factors such as mortgage arrangements and legal checks.

questions.q: What is an NIE and how do I get one?
questions.a: An NIE (Número de Identidad de Extranjero) is a tax identification number for foreigners. You can obtain it through the Spanish consulate in your country or at a police station in Spain. We can assist with this process.

questions.q: Do I need a Spanish bank account?
questions.a: Yes, a Spanish bank account is necessary for paying utilities and local taxes. It’s also required if you’re taking out a Spanish mortgage.

questions.q: Is it necessary to make a will in Spain?
questions.a: While not mandatory, it’s highly recommended to make a Spanish will for your property to ensure smooth inheritance proceedings and avoid complications with international succession laws.

questions.q: What’s the difference between urban and rural properties?
questions.a: Urban properties are located within town boundaries with access to main services. Rural properties might have more land but could have restricted building rights and limited access to utilities.

questions.q: Can I renovate or extend my property?
questions.a: Yes, but you’ll need proper permits from the local town hall. Regulations vary between urban and rural areas, and some properties may have restrictions.

questions.q: What ongoing costs should I expect?
questions.a: Regular costs include IBI (council tax), community fees if applicable, utilities, insurance, and non-resident income tax if you’re not a resident.

cta.heading: Still Have Questions?
cta.text: Our team is here to help you with any questions you might have about buying property in inland Spain.

metadata.title: Understanding Unpaid Taxes on Spanish Property | Inland Andalucia
metadata.description: Learn about the implications of unpaid taxes when buying property in Spain, how to check for tax debts, and protect yourself during property purchase.

header.title: Understanding Unpaid Taxes
header.description: When buying property in Spain, it's crucial to understand the implications of any unpaid taxes associated with the property. Here's what you need to know to protect yourself.

warning.title: Important Warning
warning.text: In Spain, unpaid taxes associated with a property become the responsibility of the new owner. This makes it essential to conduct proper checks before completing any purchase.

types.title: Types of Tax Debts to Check

items.label: IBI (Council Tax)
items.text: Annual property tax paid to the local town hall

items.label: Community Fees
items.text: For properties within a community or urbanization

items.label: Plusvalía
items.text: Tax on the increase in land value

items.label: Income Tax
items.text: If the property has been rented

checks.title: How to Check for Unpaid Taxes
checks.intro: Several checks should be conducted before purchasing a property:
steps: Request a certificate from the town hall showing any outstanding IBI payments
If applicable, obtain confirmation from the community administrator that all fees are up to date
Check with the Land Registry for any registered debts or charges
Verify with the tax office that there are no outstanding tax obligations

cards.title: Legal Representation
cards.text: Always use a qualified lawyer who can conduct proper due diligence and verify there are no outstanding debts before proceeding with the purchase.

cards.title: Documentation
cards.text: Ensure all certificates and clearance documents are obtained and verified before signing the final purchase contract.

commitment.title: Our Commitment
commitment.intro: At Inland Andalucia, we ensure that:
points: All properties listed have been checked for outstanding debts
Necessary documentation is available for review
Our legal partners can conduct additional checks if required
You're protected throughout the buying process

cta.title: Need Professional Assistance?
cta.text: Our team can help you verify any property's tax status and connect you with trusted legal experts.

metadata.title: Spanish Mortgages Guide | Inland Andalucia
metadata.description: Complete guide to getting a mortgage in Spain. Learn about Spanish mortgage options, requirements, costs, and how to apply as a foreign buyer.

header.title: Spanish Mortgages Guide
header.description: Understanding Spanish mortgages is crucial when buying property. Here's everything you need to know about financing your property purchase in Spain.

resident.title: Resident Mortgages
resident.point1: Up to 80% financing for primary residences

requirements.title: Requirements for Non-Resident Buyers
requirements.intro: To apply for a mortgage in Spain as a non-resident, you'll need:
requirements.point2: Proof of income (usually last 3-6 months of payslips)
requirements.point3: Tax returns from your home country
requirements.point5: Proof of employment or business ownership
requirements.point7: List of current assets and liabilities

costs.title: Associated Costs
costs.intro: When taking out a mortgage, budget for these additional costs:
costs.point2: Mortgage arrangement fee (1-2% of loan amount)

fixed.title: Fixed Rate Mortgages
fixed.description: Interest rate remains the same throughout the term. Offers security in monthly payments but typically starts with a higher rate.

variable.title: Variable Rate Mortgages
variable.description: Interest rate varies with Euribor. Usually starts lower but payments can change over time. Most common in Spain.

process.title: The Application Process
process.step1: Initial consultation and assessment of options

cta.title: Ready to Explore Your Mortgage Options?
cta.description: Our team can connect you with trusted Spanish mortgage advisors who specialize in non-resident mortgages.

content.paragraph1: The autonomous region of Andalucia lies in the the south of Spain, and its coasts are bathed by both the Mediterranean and Atlantic oceans.
content.paragraph2: It borders Extremadura and Castile-La Mancha in the north, Murcia and the Mediterranean Sea in the east, the Mediterranean and Atlantic ocean in the south, and Portugal in the west. The region's scenery stands out because of its sheer diversity. Some areas are covered in mountains while others are full of plains. There are three distinct geographical structures: the sierra Morena to the north, the Guadalquivir river and Betica depression in the central part of the region, and the Betica mountain ranges in the south.
content.paragraph3: The two most notable mountainous areas are the sub-Betica range, containing La Sagra massif that reaches an altitude of 2,383 metres and the Penibetica mountain range. The Sierra Nevada is also outstanding and is home to el Mulhacen, the highest mountain peak on the Iberian Peninsula reaching a height of 3,481 metres. Next comes Veleta peak at 3,392 metres. Andalucian rivers that lead into the Mediterranean sea are relatively short and contain small amounts of water. Amongst these are the Almanzora, the Almeria, the Adra, the Guadalfeo, the Guadalhorce and the Guadiaro. The rivers that flow into the Atlantic are bigger and have more copious waters. The region's most important river is the Guadalquivir and its tributaries: the Guadalimar, the Guadiana Menor and the Genil. The Guadiana, the Odiel and the Tinto rivers also flow into the Atlantic.
content.paragraph4: The vast stretch of coast that extends along Andalucia is filled with bays and inlets, some a little more craggy than others as we near the Betica mountain ranges. The most notable geographical quirks that are found along the coast include: the steep rock summit of Farallon, Polacra point, Gata cape, the gulf of Almeria, las Entinas point, Adra bay, Sacratif bay, Malaga bay and Calaburras point. Europa Point forms the Gibraltar headland. This is where the Spanish coast begins stretching from the straits of Gibraltar up to the cape of Trafalgar. Within the straits the most notable parts of the landscape are formed by Algeciras bay as well as by Marroqui (Moroccan) and Tarifa points.
